titleStmt.title: Barrier Lyapunov Function Based Learning Control of Hypersonic Flight Vehicle With AOA Constraint and Actuator Faults

affiliation.orgName: University of Science and Technology Beijing

analytic.title: Barrier Lyapunov Function Based Learning Control of Hypersonic Flight Vehicle With AOA Constraint and Actuator Faults

biblStruct.note: received October 1, 2017; revised November 17, 2017 and December 18, 2017; accepted January 11, 2018.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper investigates a fault-tolerant control of the hypersonic flight vehicle using back-stepping and composite learning. With consideration of angle of attack (AOA) constraint caused by scramjet, the control laws are designed based on barrier Lyapunov function. To deal with the unknown actuator faults, a robust adaptive allocation law is proposed to provide the compensation. Meanwhile, to obtain good system uncertainty approximation, the composite learning is proposed for the update of neural weights by constructing the serial-parallel estimation model to obtain the prediction error which can dynamically indicate how the intelligent approximation is working. Simulation results show that the controller obtains good system tracking performance in the presence of AOA constraint and actuator faults. Index Terms-Angle of attack (AOA) constraint, barrier Lyapunov function (BLF), composite learning, fault-tolerant control (FTC), hypersonic flight vehicle (HFV).

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: H YPERSONIC flight vehicle (HFV) plays the vital role in potential civil and military application due to the high speed flight faster than 5 mach. Several hypersonic flight tests have been conducted such as X-43, X-51, Falcon HTV-2, and SHEFEX [1]. The key technologies have been conducted on the material, structure, propulsion system, and controller design.

Control of HFV is challenging since strong coupling exists between the propulsion system, the elastic airframe, and the structural dynamics. In literature, several typical analyzed dynamics can be found as winged-cone model [2], truth model [3], curve-fitted model [4], and control-oriented model (COM) [4].

Model uncertainty caused by the varying aerodynamic parameters may affect the control accuracy. Since the dynamics is statically unstable and the system is sensitive to the environment, additional control efforts must be applied to make the system stable. To make the flight feasible, different control methods have been investigated, such as sliding-mode control [5], [6], linear output-feedback control [7], dynamic inversion design [8], back-stepping control [9], and intelligent control [10], [11]. The input saturation [12], [13], the input nonlinearity [14], and the actuator faults [15], [16] are intensively studied to guarantee the flight safety. For more details about the flight dynamics and control methods for HFV, the comprehensive reviews can be found in [17] and [18].

It is noted that the back-stepping scheme is efficient to deal with the cascade structure of the flight dynamics since the nth order complex dynamics can be divided into n oneorder subsystem and then the adaptive and robust design can be implemented. Due to the existence of unknown dynamics, the intelligent control using fuzzy logic system and neural network (NN) as approximator is widely studied. In this way, the prior knowledge of the linear parameterized model for adaptive control or the upper bound for robust control is not required. For intelligent control, some recent works can be found in [19]- [24]. While most papers on the topic of intelligent control is directly toward system stability using system tracking error to tune the weights, recently the technique of composite learning [25]- [27] is gaining attention where the fundamental idea is to include the approximation performance into the update law. In this way the learning speed can be faster while the precision can be higher. The controller design is applied to flexible manipulator [28], marine vessel [29], quadrotor [30], HFV [31], re-entry vehicle [32], etc.

Though there have been much progress in the controller design dealing with system uncertainty, the problem of angle of attack (AOA) constraint is not gaining enough attention. Air-breathing HFV use supersonic combustion ramjet (scramjet) as the propulsion system to achieve sustained hypersonic flight [33]. To make the scramjet work perfectly, the AOA during air-breathing flight should be restricted to a given interval to ensure efficiency of intake and combustion [34]. In experiments, to overcome this problem, the engineers will model the flight dynamics and then apply a predesigned trajectory to verify whether the attitude can be controlled to fulfill the scramjet requirement. In literature, several studies 2168-2267 c 2018 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.
have concentrated on state-constraint problems of HFV control [35], [36]. However, the design cannot be proved that the AOA would be guaranteed to fall into predefined interval in theory.

In [37], using transformation the error constraint is converted to new error without constraint. In [38] the output-constrained control method is developed using barrier Lyapunov function (BLF) instead of the conventional quadratic Lyapunov function. The main feature of BLF is that when the system approaches to the predefined bound, the value of BLF will go to infinity and in this way the constraint design will be successfully applied to the dynamics. Different from the output constraint control [37]- [40], the problem of AOA constraint is the state constraint. There are also several attempts in state-constrained problems [41]- [43] using BLF. One concern should be addressed how to guarantee the boundedness of the virtual control during the back-stepping design. In [44], the work dealing with AOA constraint of HFV is given using the idea of filter design in [35]. However, in [44] the design is using the pitch angle dynamics instead of the AOA dynamics and additional signal bound is required to make sure of the AOA constraint. As a result the design requires more than one BLFs.

Another problem in hypersonic flight control is the possible actuator faults which will cause the system instability. Due to the limited space, the related literature review of faulttolerant control (FTC) can be found in [16] and the detail is not discussed here. In this paper, considering the hypersonic flight dynamics with AOA constraint, actuator faults and model uncertainty, a composite learning FTC using backstepping is proposed. The main contributions of this paper are listed as follows.

1) The back-stepping control is proposed in consideration of the AOA constraint by introducing the BLF. Meanwhile, the virtual control of AOA is restricted via a saturation function. Combining the constraint on both virtual control and tracking error, the AOA could be successfully restricted into the given interval. Considering the model uncertainty and actuator fault, the composite learning is proposed for the update of neural weights and fault tolerant parameters by constructing the prediction error obtained from the serial-parallel estimation model (SPEM).
2) The closed-loop system stability is rigorously established via Lyapunov approach. The tracking errors are guaranteed to be bounded while the constraint of AOA can be guaranteed theoretically.

3) The method is simulated via hypersonic flight dynamics with AOA constraint and actuator faults. Results show that the design can guarantee the AOA to fall into the given interval while the system can adapt to actuator fault autonomously. This paper is organized as follows. The longitudinal dynamics of HFV is described in Section II. Section III presents the BLF-based back-stepping controller design, while Section IV analyzed the closed-loop system stability. The simulation results are presented in Section V. Finally, the conclusion is presented in Section VI.

div.head: II. HFV DYNAMICS AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
A. Control Oriented Model
div.p: The COM [4] is considered as
div.formula: V = T cos α -D m -g sin γ (1) ḣ = V sin γ (2) γ = L + T sin α mV - g cos γ V (3) α = q -γ(4)
div.p: q = M yy I yy (5) where V, h, γ , α, and q represent velocity, altitude, flight path angle (FPA), AOA, and pitch rate, respectively, while T, L, D, and M yy represent thrust, lift, drag force, and pitch moment, respectively, with the following expressions:
div.formula: T = T (α) + T 0 (α) ≈ qS C α 3 T α 3 + C α 2 T α 2 + C α T α + C 0 T + qS C α 3 T α 3 + C α 2 T α 2 + C α T α + C 0 T D ≈ qS C α 2 D α 2 + C α D α + C 0 D L = L 0 + L α α ≈ qSC 0 L + qSC α L α M yy = M T + M 0 (α) + M δ e u f ≈ z T T + qSc C α 2 M α 2 + C α M α + C 0 M + qScC δ e M u f
div.p: where is the fuel equivalence ratio.
In this paper, the following actuator-fault model is considered:
div.formula: u f = μ • [u + ϕ(ū -u)] (6
div.p: where μ = [μ Assumption 1: For the hypersonic flight dynamics, for any up to m-1 actuator failures with failure values ūj , time instants t j and pattern ϕ, the remaining actuators can still achieve the control goal.
Remark 1: Assumption 1 is commonly used in FTC related research to make sure the system is with enough capability to recover from the actuator fault.
Due to the limited space, the details of the aircraft dynamics and system fault definition is omitted here. The discussion can be found in [16].

div.head: B. Dynamics Transformation
div.p: For the altitude subsystem (2)-( 5), define the altitude error e h = hh r , where h r is the reference signal of altitude. According to [10], the FPA command could be designed as
div.formula: x 1d = arcsin -k h e h -k i e h dt + ḣr /V (7)
div.p: where k h and k i are the positive design constants.
Assumption 2: Generally T sin α is much smaller than L, therefore T sin α could be neglected.
Define x 1 = γ , x 2 = α, and x 3 = q, the subsystem (3)-( 5) could be transformed to the following form:

div.p: Remark 3: In this paper, the unknown functions f i will be approximated by radial-basis-function (RBF) NN. It is known that for an arbitrary real continuous function f i on a compact set X in ∈ R M , there exist the following RBF NNs and an optimal parameter vector ω * i such that:
div.formula: f i = ω * T i θ i + ε i (9)
div.p: where |ε i | < ε im and ε im > 0 is the supremum of reconstruction error ε i .

div.formula: ln k 2 b k 2 b -e 2 < e 2 k 2 b -e 2 . (10

div.head: C. Control Goal
div.p: To control the hypersonic flight dynamics, based on functional decomposition, the velocity subsystem and altitude subsystem are obtained. For the altitude subsystem, considering the model uncertainty, AOA constraint and actuator faults, a composite learning FTC is proposed to steer the altitude to track a desired trajectory. For the velocity subsystem, a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) controller is designed to ensure velocity tracking.

div.head: III. CONTROLLER DESIGN
div.p: Considering the third-order system (8), the back-stepping controller is designed in this section. The BLF is employed to deal with the AOA constraint during the analysis. The system uncertainties are estimated by NNs, where both tracking error and prediction error are employed in updating laws. For the actuator fault, the robust adaptive design is presented.
Step 1: Define the FPA tracking error e 1 = x 1x 1d . The derivative of e 1 is obtained as
where ω * 1 is the optimal NN weights vector, θ 1 (x 1 ) is the basis function vector, and ε 1 is the NN approximation error satisfying |ε 1 | ≤ τ 1m with τ 1m as the upper bound of ε 1 .
Choose the virtual control of the pitch angle x 2 as
div.formula: x 2c = 1 ĝ1 -ωT 1 θ 1 (x 1 ) -k 1 e 1 + ẋ1d -τ1m tanh z 1 0 (12)
div.p: where k 1 > 0 is the gain parameter, ω1 is the estimation of ω * 1 , ĝ1 = ωg1 θ g1 is the estimation of g 1 , τ1m is the estimation of τ 1m , and z 1 is defined in (17).

div.p: Remark 4: The projection in ( 22) is to make sure the signal ωgi falls into the interval [ω gi , ωgi ].

Remark 5: The constraint on e 2 is introduced in ( 27) and (37) to restrict AOA tracking error. The saturation function is used to restrict the virtual control x 2c . By combining the constraint on both virtual control and tracking error, the AOA could be restricted to (-x 2m , x 2m ).

Remark 6: Different from the BLF-based AOA-constraint study in [44], the definition of x 2 in altitude subsystem is the AOA, and the corresponding model transformation is obtained. Thus, the constraint on AOA could be directly achieved in controller design and the additional conversions on FPA and pitch angle in [44] could be eliminated.

div.p: The derivative of L A is obtained as
div.formula: LA ≤ - i=1,3 k i e 2 i -k 2 ln k 2 b ψ - 3 i=1 β i - 1 2 γ zi x2 i - 3 i=1 1 2 δ i ωT i ωi - 3 i=1 1 2 ν i τ 2 im - i=1,3 1 2 ξ i ω2 gi - j =j p 1 2 ζ 1j k2 1j + 1 2 ζ 2j k2 2j + 3 i=1 1 2 δ i ω * i 2 + 3 i=1 1 2 γ zi ε 2 im + 3 i=1 1 2 ν i τ 2 im + 3 i=1 τ im κ 0 + i=1,3 1 2 ξ i ω2 gi + j =j p 1 2 ζ 1j k 2 1j + 1 2 ζ 2j k 2 2j ≤ -σ L A + P (67
div.p: where
div.formula: σ = min [2k i , 2(β i -(1/2)), δ i γ i , ν i ι i , ξ 1 η 1 , ξ 3 η 3 , ζ 1j 1j , ζ 2j ] and P = 3 i=1 (1/2)δ i ω * i 2 + 3 i=1 (1/2)γ zi ε 2 im + 3 i=1 (1/2)ν i τ 2 im + ε 1m κ 0 + 3 i=1 τ im κ 0 + i=1,3 (1/2)ξ i ω2 gi + j =j p ((1/2)ζ 1j k 2 1j + (1/2)ζ 2j k 2 2j ). Furthermore, it is known that 0 ≤ L A ≤ P σ + L A (0) - P σ e -σ t . (68
div.p: When t → ∞, L A → (P/σ ). It is known all the signals in (52) are uniformly ultimately bounded. Furthermore, according to [39, Lemma 1], the signal
div.formula: x 2 satisfies |x 2 | < x 2cm + k b , ∀t > 0.
div.p: This completes the proof. Remark 7: In Lyapunov analysis, the following symmetric BLF candidate is chosen and included in L 2 :
div.formula: L b = 1 2 ln e 2 2 k 2 b -e 2 2 .
div.p: (69) Remark 8: To make sure of the boundedness of x 2 , the constraint is applied to the virtual control signal x 2c to obtain the bounded filter value x 2cl . The design is motivated by the work in [35]. In this way, as long as e 2 is bounded within the certain compact, x 2 will be constrained to the predefined range.

Remark 9: The controller design in this paper is mainly using the back-stepping scheme. However, it is different from our previous works. For example, in [16], the command filter design is used while in this paper the differentiator is employed. Furthermore, the fault tolerant algorithms in (47) and ( 48) are proposed with the prediction error. Also kindly noted that there are tyros [16, eqs. (40) and (41)] and it should be with k1i and k2i .

Remark 10: In the stability analysis, only z 1 is guaranteed to be bounded. As discussed in the command filter design, if the limitation (13) is not working, z 10 will converge to zero and the signal e 1 is bounded.

div.head: V. SIMULATION
div.p: For the velocity control, define the velocity tracking error V = V r -V, where V r is the velocity reference signal. The following PID control law is employed:
div.formula: = k pv Ṽ + k iv Ṽ(t)dt + k dv d Ṽ(t) dt (70
div.p: where k pv , k iv , and k dv are the PID parameters and selected as 0.5, 0.001, and 0.001. The initial state variables are set as h 0 = 86 000 ft, v 0 = 7850 ft/s, γ 0 = 0 rad, α 0 = 0 rad, and q 0 = 0 rad/s. The controller gain parameters are selected as k 1 = 1, k 2 = 1, and k 3 = 40. The parameters of the differentiator are set as p 20 = 0.1, p 30 = 10, p 21 = 0.1, and p 31 = 10 while the RBF NN parameters are chosen as γ 1 = 0.1, γ 2 = 0.01, γ 3 = 0.01, δ 1 = 10, δ 2 = 0.001, δ 3 = 10, and γ zi = 0.001, i = 1, 2, 3. The parameters of SPEM are chosen as β 1 = β 2 = β 3 = 2. In adaptive laws ( 21) and ( 41), the parameters are chosen as η 1 = 10 -7 and η 3 = 10 -7 . In adaptive laws ( 23), (31), and (42), For the constraint of AOA, k b is set as 0.02, x 2cm = 0.08, consequently the maximum absolute value of AOA will be limited to 0.1 rad. In the study, two control inputs u 1 and u 2 are considered while μ 1 and μ 2 are set as 1. The system fault occurs at 20 s. For the altitude climbing task, in the first 50 s, the step of 200 ft is considered and then another step command of 500 ft is given for the flight dynamics while the velocity is controlled to be constant. For the filter of the step command, the same one is employed as in [10].

The simulation results are shown in Figs. 123456789. From Fig. 1, the system altitude can follow the reference signal very well. Furthermore, from the response of AOA in Fig. 2, the value is successfully controlled to the predefined interval. Also it is noticed that at the beginning of each climbing, the AOA try to cross the value of 0.08 rad. According from the response of the control inputs shown in Fig. 3, the elevator deflection is changing fast to make sure that the AOA is under control in [1.5, 4] s and [50,54] s. During this period as shown in Fig. 5, the compensation signal z 10 is not zero. From the response of e 2 in Fig. 5, the maximum value 0.001 is smaller than k b = 0.002 which means the BLF-based design is in effect. The NN weights response is shown in Fig. 6 and due to the constraint of AOA, the response of ω2 is changing accordingly. The FPA and pitch rate are demonstrated in Fig. 4. The estimations of control gain functions, fault tolerant parameter and the robust items are depicted in Figs. 789, respectively. From the response in Fig. 3, the actuator 2 is stuck at the 20th s where the value becomes constant, while the actuator 1 is adapting according to the update of k11 and k21 . From the simulation test, it confirms that the proposed approach can adapt to the system uncertainty, AOA constraint and actuator fault.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, the AOA constraint and actuator faults are considered in HFV controller design. In order to restrict the AOA, the constraints on both virtual control and tracking error of AOA are introduced in controller design, where the control laws are modified based on BLF. Besides, composite learning technique and actuator adaptive distribution laws are included in the controller. Simulation is conducted to verify that the method could obtain good tracking performance when model uncertainty and actuator faults exist, while the AOA could be restricted into the predefined interval. For future work, the adaptive dynamic programming related learning control in [46]- [48] can be considered for optimal control of hypersonic flight. Also the FTC [49] and the datadriven control [50] can be further included in the scheme for more complex control task.

The signals ω gi , i = 1, 3 have the upper bounds ωgi and the lower bounds ω gi , where ωgi and ω gi are known in prior.
